prospects.name: Gran Canaria: Lake Chira
prospects.description:
Our first ever On Location gravel adventure and what a ride we have in store! This one may be short but it’ll have you hanging onto the edge of your saddle as we explore the Pilancones Natural Park, high up on a mountain ridge overlooking the Soria valley as we head towards Chira Lake. The goal of this ride will be to work on your good form with a slightly higher cadence than normal, keeping the legs supple and spinning. We’ll gently build the effort up a 3km climb to get the heart, legs and lungs working a little harder before descending to our final destination at Chira Lake. This workout is perfect for those days when you need an easier session or want to activate the body before going deeper.

​

This workout focusses on a progressive build through the duration of the climb helping with your pacing skills and sustained efforts.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/8773915186)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Open: 30
prospects.description: Sometimes you just need a steady endurance ride to clear the legs and head out to make room for more serious sessions. This workout is set for a steady 65% FTP, but you can adjust the intensity whenever you like to match your workout goals. The video for this session features footage from the Col Collective.

prospects.name: G.O.A.T.
prospects.description:
This session is all about high-torque efforts, very similar to the efforts you would experience riding up the steep slopes of Mt Sufferlandria. While these efforts are short and the intensity isn’t too high, the low cadence targets combined with minimal recovery will leave some begging for the high-cadence sprints of _The Omnium_. High-torque efforts like these have two primary benefits: improved neuromuscular coordination and increased muscular endurance.

​

During each pedal revolution, your legs have to “switch on” and “switch off” almost all of the muscles in your legs. High-cadence efforts in something like _Cadence Builds_ are great for teaching these groups to make that switch quickly. These low-cadence efforts are better for teaching ALL of the muscles in your legs to “switch on.” Done properly, you should be pulling with your hamstrings with one leg while the other leg is pushing down with all the force your glutes and quads can muster. If you feel like you are pushing yourself up out of the saddle during harder efforts (like seated sprints), your hamstrings are not being utilized since they should pull you back down into your saddle.

​

The second main benefit is improved muscular endurance. Even though the session is under 45 minutes, **you'll put a similar amount of muscular fatigue into your legs as a steady, multi-hour base ride.** You can almost view this session as hitting the leg press for 8 sets of 100 reps. And just like the weight room, proper form is absolutely key. That means:

- You should focus on pushing down AND pulling back up. You want your glutes and quads activated on the way down and your hamstring and hip flexors activated on the way up.
- To properly engage your hamstrings think about trying to pulling your heel up to your butt when your crank arm is going from 6 o’clock to 10 o’clock.
- Your knees should be tracking straight up and down, no collapsing in or out.
- Your core should be fully engaged to keep your hips steady in the saddle. This will be easier if you are both pushing and pulling during each pedal revolution.

This session is very similar to _Power Station_. Both help improve your muscular endurance and coordination; the biggest difference is the work to rest ratio between the two. While the intervals here are shorter than those in _Power Station_, the decreased recovery duration means fatigue will build faster, especially for those with a weakness in repeated efforts.

Modifying interval length and recovery duration can also be seen between sessions like _Revolver_ and _A Very Dark Place_. Both serve up a healthy dose of MAP/VO2 work, but the overall feeling of those two sessions is different.

If you find that your lower back starts to ache during this session or that you have to start rocking in the saddle to keep the power up, then it’s time for you to get started on the SYSTM Yoga program. Kick it off with “Core Strengtheners ” to make sure your core is just as strong as those legs.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[When to Train with Low Cadence](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/when-to-train-with-low-cadence)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Sports Science.

prospects.name: Tempo Builds: 3 x 7
prospects.description:
This tempo session may not look very tough, but take a look at the recovery intervals...you only get 3 minutes at 65%. That's not a leisurely pace, which means that you'll go into the next 7 minute build with some fatigue still in the legs. The combination of partial recoveries and effort building intervals will leave you feeling like you've done more than 21 minutes at tempo by the end. The build format of each of the 7-minute efforts is also great for working on your negative split pacing which is great for everyone, but especially important if you're a time trialist or triathlete. With nice long ramps to warmup and cool down, you should feel good going into the main set and be able to recover fairly quickly when finished.

​

**Warm Up **

3 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%
10 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%
1 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

1 minute @ RPE 4 -- 70% of FTP -- HR <80%

2 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

2 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort **

Number of sets: 3

Rest between sets: 3 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval repeats per: NA

**Interval **

4 minutes @ RPE 5 -- 80% of FTP -- HR <80%

2 minutes @ RPE 5.5 -- 85% of FTP -- HR <90%

1 minute @ RPE 6 -- 85% of FTP -- HR <100

​

**Extra Volume **

N/A

​

**Cool Down **

6 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

4 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Ruta Chingaza
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2020): In February, legendary ultra-endurance cyclist Lael Wilcox, Joe Cruz, and filmmaker Rugile Kaladyte traveled to the Colombian capital, in partnership with Conservation International, Wahoo, and Bikepacking.com to launch the Bikepacking for Conservation Program. The project was designed to explore and scout a bikepacking route that would connect the bustling metropolis of Bogota, Colombia with rural communities and the Chingaza National Park. The resulting route — Ruta Chingaza — will help cyclists connect to nature and better understand the ecosystems upon which life and livelihoods in this area depend.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session. Intensity is low, with power remaining at or below 50% of FTP (2.5 on a scale from 1 to 10) with heart rate targets entirely in Zone 1. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting, but not so much that it distracts you from the story.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Cadence Builds
prospects.description:
One of the best sessions for neuromuscular training, this drill asks you to progressively build from a cadence of 90 RPM to your MAX over 30 seconds, recover, and repeat several times. Cadence builds improve how you recruit your leg, gluteal, and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke by progressing to your maximal cadence. By reaching your highest cadence possible, you are training the 'on/off' switch in each muscle group to not only work faster but to have less overlap with your other muscle groups. This session trains your hamstring muscles to 'turn off' when your quads 'turn on' and vice-versa, resulting in a more efficient pedal stroke at both high and low cadences.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

prospects.name: Across the Mountains
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2020): _Across the Mountains_ follows legendary cyclist Michael Cotty through two different adventures. The first, _Les Alpes_, is the story of Mike's non-stop ride from Evian-Les-Bains to Nice across the heart of the Alps: a journey of 677km with 17 mountain passes and more than 16,000 meters of climbing. The second, _The Road to Mont Blanc_, sees Mike tackle a 1,000 km non-stop journey across 21 mountains in the Dolomites, Eastern and Swiss Alps before finishing at Mont Blanc. Featuring never-before-seen footage and exclusive commentary by Mike Cotty himself.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session. Intensity is low, with power remaining at or below 50% of FTP (2.5 on a scale from 1 to 10) with heart rate targets entirely in Zone 1. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting, but not so much that it distracts you from the story.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

​

prospects.name: Bavaria: Oberjoch
prospects.description:
Saddle up and prepare to conquer Oberjoch, the signature climb of the region, taking us through Bavaria’s lush pastures towards Austria’s scenic Lake Haldensee.

​

This workout features a series of low and high cadence drills with a progressive intensity build. We’ll kick off the climb with a 4-minute low cadence interval at 80-85% FTP, followed by a 2-minute recovery. From there, each interval shortens by one minute, while the cadence and effort increase slightly, alternating between low and high cadence to maintain focus and form.

Once we reach the summit, it’s time to recover briefly before diving into the second part of the session: five 60-second tempo-to-threshold builds on the flat toward Haldensee. This workout is designed to improve aerobic efficiency, strength, and your ability to recover between hard efforts. Sounds simple? Let’s chat at the end—good luck!

​

The intervals will alternate between low and high cadence requiring you to ride at an exceptionally low cadence to stress your muscular system more than your cardiovascular system and then riding at 100+ RPM has the exact opposite effect with less strain on your muscles, but a greater strain on your cardiovascular system. Alternating back and forth between low and high cadence will ensure both your muscular system and cardiovascular system get pushed hard.

The tempo builds will work you hard but flush out your legs making your recovery quicker so you can go hard tomorrow.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9853644571)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: French Pyrenees: Cirque de Gavarnie
prospects.description:
This ride finds you in the French Pyrenees to ride the gently climbing valley road up to the world-famous Cirque de Gavarnie. Starting in Luz-Saint-Sauveur, you'll work your way up the road with a series of low cadence strength work, some threshold work, and then a series of over/under efforts. As you ride, Mike will show you around the Bridge of Napolean III, the famous regional spit cakes, a river full of grain mills, and maybe even a bottle or two of the local craft beer.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/3831540078)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Puerto de la Vall de Ebo (Recharger Ride)
prospects.description:
This is an active recovery ride built with purpose. Low-intensity endurance work is paired with brief high-cadence neuromuscular activations to keep the nervous system awake without creating new fatigue. You’ll stay well below threshold throughout, allowing your body to absorb previous hard sessions and prepare for what’s ahead.

​

Set on the peaceful roads leading to the summit of Port de la Vall d’Ebo, this ride promotes circulation, technique, and mental reset. It’s ideal after race days or big training blocks — a smart session that helps you recover better, so you can train harder tomorrow. No ego, no watts chasing — just intentional recovery done right.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/13996505846)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Igniter
prospects.description:
A highly tuned machine needs its engine warmed up in order to produce the most power as efficiently as possible. Igniter is based on the highly successful warm-up session developed by British Cycling and used by Team Sky as part of their 'marginal gains' program. You'll go through a series of progressive efforts before hitting a couple of high-intensity/high-cadence sprints. You'll emerge ready to CRUSH EVERYTHING BEFORE YOU! This workout is perfect before major events, in conjunction with our Extra Shot workout, or to extend your regular session.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to why warm-ups are so important in this episode of The Knowledge podcast by Wahoo Sports Science:

[https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine](https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine)
prospects.notes: Just running through a practice warm-up today.

prospects.name: # Getting Away With It (November Groundwork Challenge)
prospects.description:
This workout is part of the Wahoo X Monthly Challenge. Click [++here++](https://wahoox.forum.wahoofitness.com/t/wahoo-november-challenge-groundwork/30430) to find out more.

​

Wouldn't it be great if you could leave work to go for a ride? Even for an hour? Well, now's your chance. _Getting Away With It_ gets you out of the office and onto the roads of the French Pyrenees with your guide Michael Cotty of The Col Collective.

​

This is a great session to add toward the end of a training block. The shorter duration, sub-threshold efforts are fantastic for getting some extra FTP building while you are in a fatigued state. Extra emphasis on cadence stresses your nervous system, making your body more efficient at higher and lower RPMs while improving your form. The Neuromuscular training you get from this session is fantastic, so while your power never exceeds threshold, your body will learn to bring more energy to the pedals at all intensities.

prospects.name: Look For Things Where You Can Find Them
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2025): This film is a visually stunning endurance sports film that reimagines what it means to swim, bike, and run. Professional triathlete Eric Lagerstrom sets out on a summer of self-discovery across Colorado, Arizona, and British Columbia, reconnecting with the curiosity that first pulled him into the sport.

Along the way, he rides remote gravel roads with endurance legend Heather Jackson, dives into icy open water with Olympic gold medalist Simon Whitfield, and runs high alpine ridgelines far from any race course. Together, they explore a deeper purpose in sport—one rooted in wonder, not competition.

Shot across three breathtaking locations, this is triathlon like you’ve never seen it: wild, creative, and free.

This is multi-sport without rules. Movement without limits. Adventure without a stopwatch.

​

🚴 Workout: the workout accompanying this film varies from endurance to tempo to sub-threshold. The higher intensity efforts aren't the hardest you'll experience so that you can keep your attention on the film, however, they are just hard enough to help improve your FTP, oxygen utilization efficiency, and the ability to recover quickly between hard efforts. The workout intensity reflects the intensity of the riders in many places, so you may feel as if you're climbing Mont Ventoux or that you're a part of Cav's lead-out train on the run into the finish line.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: No Place Like Home
prospects.description:
Have you been riding, but not riding too hard? Have you been putting in lots of easy and endurance rides but not much intensity? Are you ready to bring intervals back into your routine, but not quite prepared to face up to a session like _Nine Hammers_ or _The Shovel_? Then this is the session for you.

​

If you love _Recharger_ then you're going to tough love_ No Place Like Home_ - the perfect re-introduction to a little bit of hard work. It will wake up your legs, lungs and mind, reminding them what it means to dig deep but without really working too hard or for too long. The workout is expertly designed by Wahoo's Head of Sports Science, Sir Neal Henderson, as a gradual step back into Suffering when self-doubt has taken hold of you and motivation may be low. While you’re riding it, you'll soon realize that you're stronger than you think and that you _can_ work hard. You'll also realize that you really shouldn't have ever left Sufferlandria -- Border Control takes these things very seriously.

​

And when the session is finished? A wave of endorphins kicks in - and if you’ve done it right, you'll feel a sense of elation and a little sting in the legs that reminds you why you were born to Suffer and why there truly is..._No Place Like Home._

prospects.name: From the Ground Up - Season 4 Pt 2
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2024):

**Episode 4: Setting An Example**

In Episode 4 we arrive in Steamboat Springs, CO and start to settle in before race day. We pre ride the course, pick up packets and find some nerves. In our final athlete feature we dive into what drives Kristen Myers? How does the super mom do it all and still find time to train? This episodes is all about the final preparations before race day.

​

**Episode 5: Mind Over Matter**

In our last episode, we reach the culmination of all our riders hard work and arrive in Steamboat Springs, CO for the SBT GRVL race. Do they have what it takes to finish 125 miles with less than 6 months of training? Each person will battle their own self doubt as the gun goes off for the final time this season.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Catalunya: Costa Brava Coastline
prospects.description:
Today we’re going to be riding one of the most incredible roads of Spain's Catalan region, going from St Feliu de Guíxols over to Tossa de Mar and hugging the Costa Brava coastline the whole way. Continually undulating we’ll hit each of the eight rolling climbs hard, working at low cadence with high intensity to build strength. Mike will keep you focused on good form, though, and make sure you keep the power down on all the way over each summit.

​

It wouldn't be an On Location ride, though, if we didn't have a look at the scenic attractions along the way, though, so get ready for craggy rocks, turquoise clear waters, and a few opportunities to delve into the Costa Brava’s finest as we find out more about the region along this 21km route.

​

[Route on Strava](https://www.strava.com/routes/2967787441439728434)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: FTP Progression 1: 5 x 6
prospects.description:
As the title suggests, this is the first of a series of workouts designed to help you accumulate time at FTP. In simple terms, this session is 5 repeats of 6 minutes at or just below 100% of FTP with 4 minutes of easy recovery, making for a 60-minute session with 30 minutes of riding at FTP.

​

By itself, this workout is not super hard, which is the point since it is the first session of our FTP progression series. This session is great for one of your first sessions with some fresh power numbers off of completing Full Frontal to get more comfortable with your new numbers. It also makes for a great second afternoon/evening session when doing two-a-day training sessions.

​

**Warm Up **2 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70% 2 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70% 1 minute @ RPE 6.5 -- 85% of FTP -- HR <80% 1 minute @ RPE 7.5 -- 95% of FTP -- HR <80% 1 minute @ RPE 7.75 -- 105% of FTP -- HR >105% 3 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

**Main Effort **Number of Sets: 5 Rest Between Sets: 4 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70% Interval Repeats Per Set: NA **Interval **6 minute @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR >105%

**Extra Volume **N/A

**Cool Down **30 seconds @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70% 3 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70% 30 seconds @ RPE 1.5 -- 40% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Tempo High Cadence: 4 x 3
prospects.description:
The training benefit of this session comes down to the uncomfortably high cadence you need to hold during each effort. Even though these efforts are under FTP, the high leg speed required will leave your system working harder than usual for the required power output.

By maintaining the highest cadence possible (without bouncing in the saddle) you end up pushing your neuromuscular coordination near its limits in a similar way to Cadence Builds.

​

With an emphasis on low torque (high RPM) efforts this session is polar opposite to sessions like GOAT and Power Station. Even though these efforts are short and below FTP the high cadence places more of a load on your cardiovascular system, so expect your heart rate and breathing to be higher than normal for the power.

​

Since muscles can only contract (pull) any given muscle will primarily move a joint in a single direction. When it comes to pedaling a bike, your quads and glutes can push the pedals down, while your hamstrings and hip flexors pull the pedals back up (with the help of your glutes and quads on the other leg). If you were to pedal with one leg (as you do in Cadence Drills) and your hamstrings and glutes were unable to contract, once you get to the bottom of the pedal stroke your leg would be stuck down there. No matter how hard you might try, your glutes and quads will do nothing to help you get that pedal all the way around. Suppose you do have both feet clipped in, and you are letting your opposite leg push down to bring your leg back up to 12 o'clock. If your quads and glutes are still contracting (pushing the pedal down) while the glutes and quads of your other leg are starting to push their pedal down, you will end up with one leg working against the other. You must relax the glutes and quads of one leg to get all of the power out of the glutes and quads of your other leg.

This is where neuromuscular coordination comes into play. During each pedal revolution, your legs have to “switch on” and “switch off” almost all of the muscles in your legs. By maintaining your highest cadence without bouncing, you are pushing all of the muscles in each leg to contract and relax (switch on and off) as quickly as possible.

While we give specific cadence targets in this session, everyone has a different limit to what cadence they can maintain before bouncing in the saddle. To get the intended benefit of this session you need to maintain the power targets at the highest cadence that YOU can maintain. For some that might be 105RPM, for others, it might be 150RPM. What matters is that you push YOUR neuromuscular system to its limits.

​

**Warm Up**

15 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: 3

Rest between sets: 7 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

Interval repeats per: NA

**Interval**

3 minutes @ RPE 5 -- 80% of FTP -- 100+ RPM -- HR <95%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Blender (Mini Version)
prospects.description: _Mini Blender_ takes all the best parts of the SUF classic _Blender_ and condenses them into a workout that's less than 60-minutes long. The sustained efforts at the start ensure your Anaerobic Capacity (AC) and Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP) are really put to the test during the two sets of micro-intervals (the dreaded "Pain Shakes"). Just like the regular _Blender_, throwing some shorter threshold efforts your way after those AC and MAP builders means that your FTP doesn’t get left out. A perfect session for those who want to hit lots of improvement areas within an hour.

prospects.name: Tempo with Surges: 2 x 20
prospects.description: In just under one-hour, you'll be performing two twenty-minute long efforts that are broken up with short surges every few minutes to keep you on your toes and develop the ability to recover from harder efforts while still holding a relatively high power output just below threshold. WIth only 5-minutes recovery between the efforts, this session is sure to boost your sustained power output.

prospects.name: Recovery Spin
prospects.description:
Don’t be afraid of the Two Rs: rest and recovery. Believe it or not, you get faster when your body is taking it easy after all that suffering. A recovery spin is a very low intensity ride, so easy that you’d feel embarrassed to ride so slowly if you didn’t know you were helping your body get so much faster.

​

A good recovery spin is done at a cadence above 90 RPM. While keeping power below 50% of FTP, or an RPE less than 2.5, and keeping your heart rate in Zone 1 the entire time. Recovery spins can be done outdoors, but due to the low power demands, they are often easier done on the trainer. Resist the voice of your inner Sufferlandrian telling you to go faster.

​

**Main Set**

30 minute @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP-- HR <70%

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Puerto de la Vall de Ebo (Recharger Ride)
prospects.description:
This is an active recovery ride built with purpose. Low-intensity endurance work is paired with brief high-cadence neuromuscular activations to keep the nervous system awake without creating new fatigue. You’ll stay well below threshold throughout, allowing your body to absorb previous hard sessions and prepare for what’s ahead.

​

Set on the peaceful roads leading to the summit of Port de la Vall d’Ebo, this ride promotes circulation, technique, and mental reset. It’s ideal after race days or big training blocks — a smart session that helps you recover better, so you can train harder tomorrow. No ego, no watts chasing — just intentional recovery done right.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/13996505846)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Primers
prospects.description: Whether you have a 4DP® fitness test coming up, a group ride you want to smash, that event you have been training all winter for, or even just a fun route you want to have a great ride on, this is the perfect session to do the day before. Unlike other SYSTM sessions, this one should not be viewed as a stand-alone “training” session, but rather, the ace up your sleeve you pull out when that big ride comes around. The key to this session is having you spend just enough time right around threshold, with sufficient recovery between efforts and a handful of sprints to prime all of your systems for tomorrow's event.

prospects.name: Half Monty (Ramp Test)
prospects.description:
**Half Monty: The Easy One.**

​

We recommend this fitness test for:

- Newer riders
- Athletes with limited experience pacing maximal efforts / fitness testing.
- Those who are mid-plan or who just want to get a sense of where their fitness is.

The _Half Monty_ 4DP fitness test is the most accurate and complete ramp test available. While it's not as comprehensive or as accurate as our main fitness test, _Full Frontal_, it's far more approachable and easier to pace for new riders. It also doesn't require any special preparation. You just need to feel relatively fresh.

​

Based on more than a year of research (and after dozens of lab tests and thousands of online tests) and using sophisticated analysis of power and heart rate data, _Half Monty_ is far more accurate and comprehensive than standard ramp tests.

​

It also tells you more about who you are as an athlete. _Half Monty_ provides you with your FTP, Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP), and Cycling Threshold Heart Rate (cTHR), all of which we use to personalize your workout targets.

​

If you're still using the 4DP estimates when you set up your account, _Half Monty_ will also refine your AC and NM estimates (but will not do so if you've done _Full Frontal_ or manually adjusted your estimates). If you want fully accurate AC and NM, as well as your Rider Type, Strengths, Weaknesses, and training plans adjusted to those Strengths and Weaknesses, you'll need to expose yourself to the _Full Frontal_ 4DP fitness test.

​

Ready to climb the ramp? You'll need the following before you start:

- A heart rate monitor if you want the most accurate results. Don't have one? Order one [HERE](https://wahoofitness.com/devices)
- Some kind of power device connected (trainer, power meter, virtual power, etc.)
- Be ready to pay close attention to the instructions in the workout
- Be sure your profile is complete and up-to-date (Profile > About You). Accurate information helps us make our calculations

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[Why Fitness Testing Matters](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/testing-testing-1-2-3-why-fitness-testing-matters)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Sports Science.

​

[Here's some more information on how to get the most from your fitness test.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterFitnessAssessment)

prospects.name: Standing Starts
prospects.description:
_Standing Starts_ closely simulates a lifting session on the bike because it requires the engagement of your core, upper body, and lower body. It trains your ability to generate force through the pedals by ensuring you recruit ALL of your muscles to get those cranks turning. No matter your preferred discipline, these efforts are key to teaching your body to recruit all of the muscle fibers in your legs.

​

All of the benefits in this session come from hitting these 20-second efforts as hard as you possibly can. To do that, you need full recovery between each sprint, and you need to respect that recovery. These efforts should see you start at super low RPMs with very high torque. As you start and increase the effort, your cadence will naturally increase. **Your goal is to get your cadence as high as possible by the end of each 20-second effort.** To maximize your muscle recruitment, you want to both push down and pull up on the pedals at the start. Proper core engagement is a must - your legs need a good strong backboard to push against.

​

We understand that not everyone's trainer has the necessary resistance or the required stability to perform this workout as described. If you can't safely stand up, then you can get much of the same benefit by doing these efforts seated. If your trainer can’t handle the rapid change in speed or does not have high enough resistance at a super low cadence, then you can start the efforts at a higher cadence and treat them as “normal” all-out sprints.

prospects.name: Serbia Upside Down Ep. 2
prospects.description:
🎬 Film: Serbia. A small country in the Balkan Peninsula that hides some of the most beautiful natural wonders and unique cultural heritage in this part of the world. Yet it remains unknown to many. Only the alternative, curious and brave plan their journeys in this hidden gem. However, a small self-organized crew from Serbia and Germany set a mission to discover and reveal those stunning natural creations of Serbia. On a bicycle. In just five days, they traversed 450 kilometers across six mountains of Western Serbia, and climbed around 11,000 meters to film and produce what you are about to experience.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session. It's a very low-intensity ride, with your power remaining at or below 50% of FTP (an RPE less than 2.5 on a scale from 1 to 10) and your heart rate in Zone 1. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting, but not so much that it distracts you from the story.

prospects.name: The Model
prospects.description:
They say that beauty is in the eye of the beholder. And through the bleeding eyes of Sufferlandrians, what could possibly be more beautiful than the sharp, saw-tooth profile of the workout you see before you? Full of gorgeous, shapely, shimmering blocks of yellow Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP) efforts interspersed with mercifully brief and slightly inadequate recoveries, it's a real stunner.

​

But you know what's even better looking than this alluring workout? You (after you've completed the workout, that is). Originally designed by our Head of Sports Science, Neal Henderson, for his professional athletes, The Model is a beautiful portrait of MAP brutality. It's one of those sessions that you think you can't finish, but always somehow do. It will leave you breathless, feeling all tingly, a bit confused and lying in a blubbering heap. It's a look. It will also deliver a nice boost to your fitness that always looks and feels good.

​

A true love letter to the beauty of professional cycling, The Model features a banging soundtrack and thrilling footage from both the men's and women's pelotons. With its eclectic design, effects, and graphics, you'll find yourself unable to tear your eyes away from the action on screen (assuming you can lift them from your stem).

prospects.name: FTP Progression 2: 5 x 7
prospects.description:
As the title suggests, this is the second addition to our FTP series, designed to help you improve your threshold. This workout is simply 5 repeats of 7 minutes at 96-100% of FTP with 3 minutes of easy recovery, making for a 60-minute session with 35 minutes of riding at FTP.

​

You should be getting comfortable with your fresh power numbers from your recent Full Frontal test and feel like you're gaining strength and fitness from completing the first FTP Progression workout a few times. This session has added one minute to the FTP intervals and removed a minute from the recovery sections, getting you closer to that final version of 5 x 9 min efforts with only 3 minutes recovery in between.

​

**Warm Up**

2 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

2 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 6.5 -- 85% of FTP -- HR <80%

1 minute @ RPE 7.5 -- 95% of FTP -- HR <80%

1 minute @ RPE 7.75 -- 105% of FTP -- HR >105%

3 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort** x5

Work: 7 minutes @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR >105%

Rest: 3 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

30 seconds @ RPE 1.5 -- 40% of FTP -- HR <70%

2 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

30 seconds @ RPE 1.5 -- 40% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Open: 60
prospects.description: Sometimes you just need a steady endurance ride to clear the legs and head to make room for more serious sessions. This workout is set for a steady 65% FTP, but you can adjust the intensity whenever you like to match your workout goals. The video for this session is from the 2018 Tour de Suisse.

prospects.name: The Cure
prospects.description:
Do you have Couchlandrian Tendencies? This short but powerful workout will cure you of that affliction and reassert your inner Sufferlandrian. The session is based on a combination of specific micro-intervals (made famous by Japanese coach and physiologist Izumi Tabata) that we combined with classic tempo efforts. This gives you a superb mix of Anaerobic Capacity (AC), Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP), and FTP training stresses in one short workout to help you go faster and stay stronger for longer.

​

Now, for the sports science purists among you, the 'Tabata' intervals should actually be named 'Koichi' intervals, since it was Japanese speedskating coach Irisawa Koichi who first employed the use of the 20-seconds on / 10-seconds off intervals that Dr. Izumi then confirmed via physiology lab studies to yield the best mix of maximal aerobic and anaerobic stress among the different on/off protocols that he tested.

​

For this workout, we have toned down the original intensity of the Tabata intervals to target MAP rather than Anaerobic Capacity in order to be able to complete the 20/10 micro-intervals and then follow the short efforts immediately with sustained 80-100% of FTP intervals to replicate the kind of attack and then settle efforts that are common in cycling races.

​

From a physiological perspective, you’ll produce lots of lactate during the micro-intervals. Then the goal of the tempo and FTP efforts is to stress your body’s capacity to clear that lactate as quickly as possible. Effectively, we’re trying to maximize lactate 'flux.' For each successive round of the efforts, you’ll do one less micro-interval, and the tempo efforts will get shorter. But because you’re a Sufferlandrian, they won’t get easier, and the rest between sets will get shorter. The intensity for the tempo efforts will ramp up with each repetition. Fortunately for you, there are only 3 sets of efforts and you’ll be done in just 30 minutes. If you’ve set aside an hour for this workout, you’ll be happy to have those additional 30 minutes for recovery after this session.

prospects.name: The Holy Week
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2018): The Holy Week tells the story from the eve of the Tour of Flanders right through until the tense finale on the Roubaix velodrome. Through the eyes of the riders, team staff, and devoted roadside fans, we go behind the scenes to capture the essence of the cobbled classics, and the emotions of one of the most compelling campaigns of recent years.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film varies from endurance to tempo to sub-threshold. The higher intensity efforts are low enough that they won't distract you from the story while being just hard enough to help improve your FTP, oxygen utilization efficiency, and the ability to recover quickly between hard efforts.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: 14 Vise Grips
prospects.description:
You can never have too many tools in the shed. After years of lobbying, we finally convinced Grunter von Agony to share his favorite set of implements with us: the fabled _14 Vise Grips_. Taken individually, each of the 14 intervals might appear tame, incapable of inflicting a significant squeeze. But when expertly applied in the correct order, they apply just the right kind of pressure to turn a Couchlandrian into a Sufferlandrian, just like turning coal into diamonds.

​

While the duration of each Vise Grip varies (from 30 seconds to 2 minutes), the power targets and recovery durations between them remain constant. The first 30-second interval should feel like a Sunday stroll in the park, but by the end of the first 2-minute Vise Grip, you'll be cursing Grunter's name. As the intervals get shorter, time will appear to stretch. That final 30-second effort will feel like an eternity. When you roll up to the second set, you'll know what you're in for, so just put your head down and prepare yourself to crush or be crushed.

​

Once you make it through all 14 Vise Grips, you will have been north of your Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP) for a total of 16 minutes. Changing the duration of the efforts (while keeping the same recovery) stresses your Anaerobic Capacity (AC) in a more dynamic way than, say, a more straightforward on/off session like _Half is Easy_. Since the longer efforts have the same recovery duration as the shorter ones, you will eventually deplete your AC, forcing your body to rely on your MAP to hit the required power targets. As the intervals get shorter in the second half of each set, you'll find that you have just enough left in the tank to complete the next effort.

​

Ultimately this workout combines the advantages of shorter, higher-power intervals with longer recovery (great for building muscular strength) with the advantages of longer, higher-power intervals with inadequate recovery (great for driving up your MAP and improving your AC).

prospects.name: Clobber
prospects.description:
The 3x25-minute sub-threshold workout is one of the most classic interval sessions out there, so prepare for a trip to the northern Painlands for this FTP-builder. The reason the 3x25 sub-threshold workout is so popular is that it is easy to follow, helps teach good pacing, and gives you a great threshold training stimulus.

​

In this case, you're looking at three, (roughly) 25-minute blocks at around 90% of your FTP, an effort we refer to as "Sub-Threshold". Many refer to this intensity as "Sweet-Spot", but we prefer Sub-Threshold, as the real key is to never let your power creep above your FTP. Staying just below threshold ensures that your effort remains at an intensity you know your body can handle but that is close to what would not be sustainable.

​

The only way you're going to make it through three of these efforts is if you pace yourself properly. Everyone feels just fine for the first 5 minutes of the first effort, and are often tempted to go harder. Don't be that person. More often than not, that person blows up spectacularly in the second interval, unable to finish the session. Or they have to ride that second interval at lower power, turning it into a Tempo session, which is not the goal.

​

Getting a sense of how these efforts "bite" towards the end is vital to learning how to pace yourself over longer steady-state efforts; whether that's a time trial, local climb, breakaway, triathlon, or even a good old fitness test. In each of those cases, the pacing is key. Learning how your perceived effort can steadily climb even though your power remains unchanged is critical to good pacing.

​

So how do you know if you are doing this one right? As we said, the first 5 minutes should feel relatively easy. Around that 5-minute mark, your heart rate should stop climbing, and settle into 2-5% below your Lactate Threshold Heart Rate (LTHR). If your heart rate is climbing for the entire effort and goes above your LTHR, then you are going too hard.

If you hit the 10-minute mark, your legs feel fine, and your heart rate is still in Zone 3, then you aren't going hard enough.

If you've never done a session like this before, you can consider only doing the first 20-minute effort, or even sticking to just the first 15 minutes of each effort. There's no shame in building up to this full session, so don't be afraid to pause and fast forward as needed.

​

Nailing this session is really about getting in tune with your body and understanding what the edge between a sustainable and an unsustainable effort feels like. Not being able to complete this workout is fairly common, so don't beat yourself up if you can't make it through the first few times. As long as you come away from this session with a better understanding of how to pace longer efforts, you've improved as an athlete.

prospects.name: Across the Mountains
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2020): _Across the Mountains_ follows legendary cyclist Michael Cotty through two different adventures. The first, _Les Alpes_, is the story of Mike's non-stop ride from Evian-Les-Bains to Nice across the heart of the Alps: a journey of 677km with 17 mountain passes and more than 16,000 meters of climbing. The second, _The Road to Mont Blanc_, sees Mike tackle a 1,000 km non-stop journey across 21 mountains in the Dolomites, Eastern and Swiss Alps before finishing at Mont Blanc. Featuring never-before-seen footage and exclusive commentary by Mike Cotty himself.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session. Intensity is low, with power remaining at or below 50% of FTP (2.5 on a scale from 1 to 10) with heart rate targets entirely in Zone 1. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting, but not so much that it distracts you from the story.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

​

prospects.name: Cadence Builds
prospects.description:
One of the best sessions for neuromuscular training, this drill asks you to progressively build from a cadence of 90 RPM to your MAX over 30 seconds, recover, and repeat several times. Cadence builds improve how you recruit your leg, gluteal, and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke by progressing to your maximal cadence. By reaching your highest cadence possible, you are training the 'on/off' switch in each muscle group to not only work faster but to have less overlap with your other muscle groups. This session trains your hamstring muscles to 'turn off' when your quads 'turn on' and vice-versa, resulting in a more efficient pedal stroke at both high and low cadences.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Puerto de la Vall de Ebo (Recharger Ride)
prospects.description:
This is an active recovery ride built with purpose. Low-intensity endurance work is paired with brief high-cadence neuromuscular activations to keep the nervous system awake without creating new fatigue. You’ll stay well below threshold throughout, allowing your body to absorb previous hard sessions and prepare for what’s ahead.

​

Set on the peaceful roads leading to the summit of Port de la Vall d’Ebo, this ride promotes circulation, technique, and mental reset. It’s ideal after race days or big training blocks — a smart session that helps you recover better, so you can train harder tomorrow. No ego, no watts chasing — just intentional recovery done right.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/13996505846)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Primers
prospects.description: Whether you have a 4DP® fitness test coming up, a group ride you want to smash, that event you have been training all winter for, or even just a fun route you want to have a great ride on, this is the perfect session to do the day before. Unlike other SYSTM sessions, this one should not be viewed as a stand-alone “training” session, but rather, the ace up your sleeve you pull out when that big ride comes around. The key to this session is having you spend just enough time right around threshold, with sufficient recovery between efforts and a handful of sprints to prime all of your systems for tomorrow's event.

prospects.name: Giro d'Italia 1
prospects.description:
**Featured Rider:** Attila Valter

**Event:** Giro d'Italia

**Mission:** It's the final stage of your first Grand Tour. For the past three weeks, you've battled your way across Italy. What better way to finish than leaving it all on the road in a final, short time trial. It's you against the clock in the race of truth.

​

**About ProRides**

If you’ve ever dreamed of being a professional cyclist, now’s your chance. The SYSTM ProRide series allows you to experience what it’s like to be in the biggest bike races in the world, thanks to the SYSTM 4DP® platform. We’ve taken the first-person camera footage and power data from a pro cyclist and analyzed it to determine which part of their 4DP® profile each of their efforts corresponds to. But since few of us can put down pro-level watts, we made it so all of the efforts are scaled to your own personal 4DP® profile. That means you get to experience exactly what the pros experience relative to your own abilities. When they sprint, you sprint. When they attack, you attack. When they sit up, you get to take it (relatively) easy. It's the most immersive, realistic race simulation out there.

​

[Here's some more information on how to create the most immersive ProRides experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterProRides)

​

**Featured Footage: **Velon

prospects.name: Igniter
prospects.description:
A highly tuned machine needs its engine warmed up in order to produce the most power as efficiently as possible. Igniter is based on the highly successful warm-up session developed by British Cycling and used by Team Sky as part of their 'marginal gains' program. You'll go through a series of progressive efforts before hitting a couple of high-intensity/high-cadence sprints. You'll emerge ready to CRUSH EVERYTHING BEFORE YOU! This workout is perfect before major events, in conjunction with our Extra Shot workout, or to extend your regular session.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to why warm-ups are so important in this episode of The Knowledge podcast by Wahoo Sports Science:

[https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine](https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine)

prospects.name: Rue The Day
prospects.description:
Those who have completed SUF icons like Blender, Mini Blender or the Chores will be familiar with the 40-seconds-hard/20-seconds-easy variety of Pain Shakes that Rue the Day delivers in three enticing courses. While the first few efforts in each set will feel "easy," since these blocks are stretched out to 8-minutes in length, you'll be deep into the red by the end of each set.

​

While the efforts aren't continuous, they are long enough that you accumulate plenty of time near your VO2max, which is the goal of any MAP workout. Each 8-minute set gives you more than five minutes at 90% or higher of your 5-minute peak power. By the end, you're looking at 16 minutes of accumulated MAP efforts, so get ready to say 'Hello, Pain!'

Along the way, we'll give you some interesting mental tips on how to prepare for, and better manage, the discomfort (to put it mildly) that comes with such intense efforts. In the end, you'll be both a faster and a mentally stronger cyclist.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[Demystifying VO2 and VO2MAX](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/it-takes-vo2-to-tango-demystifying-vo2-and-vo2max)' and '[The Power of Positive Mental Strategies](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/episode-29-how-to-use-positive-self-talk-to-get-through-tough-moments-on-a-ride-mental-strategies)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Sports Science.

prospects.name: The Soul of a Cyclist
prospects.description:
🎬 Film: Directed by Nuno Tavares, The Soul of a Cyclist revolves around the subject of classic bicycles**. **Shot in Portugal and in England, the film captures personal experiences of individuals who own and ride classic bicycles and their deep connection with them. A film full of curiosity, joy and adventure.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: Recovery Spin
prospects.description:
Don’t be afraid of the Two Rs: rest and recovery. Believe it or not, you get faster when your body is taking it easy after all that suffering. A recovery spin is a very low intensity ride, so easy that you’d feel embarrassed to ride so slowly if you didn’t know you were helping your body get so much faster.

​

A good recovery spin is done at a cadence above 90 RPM. While keeping power below 50% of FTP, or an RPE less than 2.5, and keeping your heart rate in Zone 1 the entire time. Recovery spins can be done outdoors, but due to the low power demands, they are often easier done on the trainer. Resist the voice of your inner Sufferlandrian telling you to go faster.

​

**Main Set**

30 minute @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP-- HR <70%

prospects.name: It Seemed Like A Good Idea At The Time (ISLAGIATT)
prospects.description:
When you want to increase your endurance and add some threshold work but only have two hours, this is the session you need. By adding in multiple surges and short chunks of time above threshold, ISLAGIATT overloads your system with metabolic byproducts ('the nasties'), which your body has to learn to clear out more efficiently.

​

Combining such long interval durations with these hard surges not only forces your body to cope with the effort, but it pushes you harder mentally because after each surge, the effort right at threshold “feels” harder than it should. With the final intervals focusing more on short, repeated efforts, you'll stress your body's ability to recover when deeply fatigued, making this more than just an “endurance builder" workout, but one that will help you keep churning out power deep into the final kilometers of challenging rides or events.

prospects.name: Tempo Alternating: 1 x 20
prospects.description:
This short, 36-minute workout will get you in and out of Sufferlandria in no time, with a solid 20 minute tempo block to boot. This continuous tempo effort will have you alternate between 75 & 85% of FTP every minute. Not only does this help pass the time rather quickly, it will help improve your aerobic fitness. Time spent in this intensity range will help increase your stroke volume (amount of blood your heart can pump every minute), your lactate threshold, and the mitochondrial density of your muscles (mitochondria are the "power houses" of the cells that create energy). All of these things are very important parts of aerobic metabolism and performing your best- especially if you like group rides. This is the typical intensity range that most group rides fall into- not a leisurely pace, but not so fast that people are falling off the back within minutes. So if you find that you commonly struggle with group rides, gradually spending more time on workouts at this intensity will have you holding on longer and taking your pulls without missing a beat!

​

**Warm Up**

6 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 6.5 -- 90% of FTP -- HR <100%

4 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: 10

Rest between sets: NA

Interval repeats per: NA

**Interval**

Work: 1 minute @ RPE 6 -- 85% of FTP -- HR <100

Steady: 1 minute @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <90%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Gran Canaria: Lake Chira
prospects.description:
Our first ever On Location gravel adventure and what a ride we have in store! This one may be short but it’ll have you hanging onto the edge of your saddle as we explore the Pilancones Natural Park, high up on a mountain ridge overlooking the Soria valley as we head towards Chira Lake. The goal of this ride will be to work on your good form with a slightly higher cadence than normal, keeping the legs supple and spinning. We’ll gently build the effort up a 3km climb to get the heart, legs and lungs working a little harder before descending to our final destination at Chira Lake. This workout is perfect for those days when you need an easier session or want to activate the body before going deeper.

​

This workout focusses on a progressive build through the duration of the climb helping with your pacing skills and sustained efforts.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/8773915186)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Galicia: Camarinas to Muxia
prospects.description:
It’s time for a wild coastal adventure with your host, Michael Cotty, across some of the stunning undulating roads of Galica, Spain. You’ll start at a historic lighthouse on the ‘Coast of Death’ before working your way deep into the rugged landscape that defines this region. The road will guide your workout, with big efforts up every hill and a chance to take it a bit easier on the descents. It’s not all hard work, though, Mike takes the time to show you around the fishing marina, where to find the ‘hunger herb’ and some of the sights around our finishing village, Muxia.

​

This is a great session for anyone who wants to get in a bit of sprint/anaerobic capacity efforts while laying down some solid aerobic time.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/7392408454)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Running With Wolves
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2018): Cyclingnews Films were granted access to Quick-Step Floors, a team that calls themselves 'The Wolfpack', to follow riders and staff throughout the three weeks of the Tour, with interviews and behind the scenes footage as the team battled it out in the biggest and toughest sporting event on the planet.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: FTP Progression 3: 5 x 8
prospects.description:
As the title suggests, this is the 3rd workout in our FTP series, designed to help you improve your sustainable power, or threshold. This session is 5 repeats of 8 minutes at 96-100% of FTP with 2 minutes of easy recovery, making for a 60-minute session with 40 minutes of riding at threshold.

By itself, this workout is not super hard, since you've likely gained some fitness throughout this progression. However, 2 minutes is not a lot of recovery time, so you may start to feel a little fatigue creep in toward the end.

​

**Warm Up**

1 minute @ RPE 1 -- 40% of FTP-- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <90%

1 minute @ RPE 6 -- 85% of FTP -- HR <100

1 minute @ RPE 7 -- 95% of FTP -- HR <100%

3 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort** x5

Work: 8 minutes @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR >105%

Rest: 2 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

1 minute @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP-- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP-- HR <70%

prospects.name: From the Ground Up - Season 3 Pt 3
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2023):

**Episode 4: Finding Balance**

We follow Megan Mouser and her journey from 3 years of FTGU. Megan is an incredible mom, self described as "Workin' on body positivity 1 mile at a time and the epitome of our community at From the Ground Up. We are so excited to finally share her story up to race day!

​

**Episode 5: Rookies Again**

What does it take for ex-NFL athletes to redefine a healthy lifestyle and take on something as foreign as riding a mountain

bike? Kawika and Amani took a leap this year, and are working to inspire and motivate other athletes post career. In this episode we look at Kawika and Amani's backgrounds and watch them learn to ride a MTB comfortably as they step onto a whole new type of playing field.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Puerto de la Vall de Ebo (Recharger Ride)
prospects.description:
This is an active recovery ride built with purpose. Low-intensity endurance work is paired with brief high-cadence neuromuscular activations to keep the nervous system awake without creating new fatigue. You’ll stay well below threshold throughout, allowing your body to absorb previous hard sessions and prepare for what’s ahead.

​

Set on the peaceful roads leading to the summit of Port de la Vall d’Ebo, this ride promotes circulation, technique, and mental reset. It’s ideal after race days or big training blocks — a smart session that helps you recover better, so you can train harder tomorrow. No ego, no watts chasing — just intentional recovery done right.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/13996505846)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Tapers
prospects.description:
When it comes to "peaking", or performing at your absolute best on a given day, the key is nailing your Taper. The term "Taper" refers to how you train in the week or so before your target event to ensure you deliver your best performance. Generally, tapering means reducing your total training volume but continuing to hit some high-intensity efforts. While there are individual variations in the best way to taper, this session has been used by countless professionals leading into the biggest races of their lives -- athletes like World Champions Rohan Dennis and Flora Duffy.

​

With 3 sets of micro-intervals (40/20s, 30/30s, and 20/40s) you will hit your system with just enough intensity to keep your legs sharp and responsive, without adding any real fatigue. Outside of those 3 sets of micro-intervals, this session is purposefully short and easy. This is a preparation session, not a training session! After all, your event is just around the corner and all of the important training is behind you. Riding harder or longer today will do absolutely nothing to increase your fitness by event day; in fact, all that would do is increase your fatigue, which will only hurt your performance. Rather, this session makes sure your body is humming along and ready to perform on the big day.

prospects.name: Open: 15
prospects.description: Sometimes you just need a steady endurance ride to clear the legs and head out to make room for a more serious session. This workout is set for a steady 65% FTP, but you can adjust the intensity whenever you like to match your workout goals. The video for this session is from the Road Race of The Hammer Series.

prospects.name: Primers
prospects.description: Whether you have a 4DP® fitness test coming up, a group ride you want to smash, that event you have been training all winter for, or even just a fun route you want to have a great ride on, this is the perfect session to do the day before. Unlike other SYSTM sessions, this one should not be viewed as a stand-alone “training” session, but rather, the ace up your sleeve you pull out when that big ride comes around. The key to this session is having you spend just enough time right around threshold, with sufficient recovery between efforts and a handful of sprints to prime all of your systems for tomorrow's event.

prospects.name: TT Event
prospects.description: Crush your TT

prospects.name: Igniter
prospects.description:
A highly tuned machine needs its engine warmed up in order to produce the most power as efficiently as possible. Igniter is based on the highly successful warm-up session developed by British Cycling and used by Team Sky as part of their 'marginal gains' program. You'll go through a series of progressive efforts before hitting a couple of high-intensity/high-cadence sprints. You'll emerge ready to CRUSH EVERYTHING BEFORE YOU! This workout is perfect before major events, in conjunction with our Extra Shot workout, or to extend your regular session.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to why warm-ups are so important in this episode of The Knowledge podcast by Wahoo Sports Science:

[https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine](https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine)

prospects.name: Total Newbie Yoga
prospects.description: Yoga-curious but don't know where to start? This session is a great place to dip your toes in. This easy, basic routine will introduce you to some simple foundational moves while giving you a little stretch and some light strength work at the same time. Think of it as the gateway drug to bringing yoga into your life.

prospects.name: Basic Yoga Poses
prospects.description: Throughout the SYSTM yoga program there are several basic, foundational moves that form the core of the routines. This session takes you through those moves in detail so you can master them and their more difficult variations.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine I
prospects.description: Are you looking for a simple stretching routine you can do on a regular basis? New to yoga? Designed for yoga beginners, this gentle yoga session will get you on the road to a more flexible you. You've said for years you'd start stretching. Now's your chance.

prospects.name: Loosen Neck and Shoulders
prospects.description: Cycling can put a lot of strain on your neck and shoulders, especially if you spend a lot of time down in the drops or in an aero position. This session will help loosen your neck and shoulders with a series of exercises that will release tension and have you feeling relaxed and ready to hit it again.

prospects.name: Morning Yoga Routine
prospects.description: In this sequence, we start with a short breathing exercise to relax the body and calm the mind, then mobilize joints throughout the body. From there we move into deeper stretches for the hips and hamstrings and finish with a short meditation.

prospects.name: Basic Yoga Poses
prospects.description: Throughout the SYSTM yoga program there are several basic, foundational moves that form the core of the routines. This session takes you through those moves in detail so you can master them and their more difficult variations.

prospects.name: Chest & Shoulder Strength
prospects.description:
This yoga sequence is designed to strengthen the upper body, targeting the shoulders, chest, triceps, and core. It's an ideal routine to practice in the morning or before a workout to activate muscles throughout the body. The intensity can be increased by lifting the knees during push-ups, providing a challenge to work towards.

​

The objectives are to strengthen the shoulders, chest, triceps, and core, practice synchronizing breath and movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Half Sun Salutations
- Triceps Push-Ups
- Plank
- Child
- Downward Dog
- Puppy
- Chest Stretch
- Triceps Stretch
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: End Of Day Stretch
prospects.description:
This slow and stretchy sequence is ideal for practicing at the end of a long day at work or after travel. It focuses on opening up the chest and shoulders, stretching the neck and forearms, and releasing tension in the calves, hamstrings, hips, and lower back. These poses can also be used after a workout for a comprehensive full-body stretch.

​

The objectives are to stretch the neck, shoulders, triceps, chest, and forearms; release tension in the lower back, hips, hamstrings, calves, ankles, and feet; transition the body into parasympathetic "rest or digest" mode after exercise; and help alleviate lower and mid back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Puppy
- Screaming Toe
- Neck Stretch
- Ankle Stretch
- Chest Stretch
- Forearm Stretch
- Downward Dog
- Revolved Standing Forward Bend
- Low Lunge Chest Opener
- Dead Pigeon
- Reclining Spinal Twist

prospects.name: Neck and Upper Back Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we improve mobility in the neck, shoulders, upper and mid-back, open up the chest and shoulders and relieve tension at the lower back to help alleviate neck, shoulder, and interscapular pain. You can practice it in the morning or the evening.

prospects.name: Recovery Booster
prospects.description: It may seem counterintuitive, but it's during recovery when you actually get stronger and consolidate the gains you've made while training. Without proper recovery, you won't improve. This session helps boost your recovery time, relaxing you and ensuring you give your body the chance to grow stronger.

prospects.name: Hip Flexor and Groin Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we release the hip flexors and groin and stretch the hamstrings and calves. It's a great session to do after a workout or in the evening to prevent and alleviate lower back pain.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine I
prospects.description: Are you looking for a simple stretching routine you can do on a regular basis? New to yoga? Designed for yoga beginners, this gentle yoga session will get you on the road to a more flexible you. You've said for years you'd start stretching. Now's your chance.

prospects.name: Lower Back Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we release tension in the hips—the groin, glutes, piriformis, TFL, and external hip rotators, stretch the calves and hamstrings and re-align the pelvis. It's a great session to practice in the morning or the evening to prevent and alleviate lower back pain.

prospects.name: Thoracic Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we improve thoracic and shoulder mobility, open up the chest and stretch the lats, shoulders, triceps, calves, and hamstrings to improve posture, facilitate better breathing and help to alleviate upper back, interscapular, and neck pain. You can practice it in the morning or the evening.

prospects.name: Foot & Ankle Recovery
prospects.description:
In this restorative sequence, the focus is on mobilizing the toes, feet, and ankles, stretching the calves and hamstrings, and opening up the hips. The session begins with a calming breathing technique, followed by a simple foot massage to introduce movement from the toes up to the heel. With increased range of motion, the routine progresses to gentle, dynamic stretches for the calves, hamstrings, and hips. Since feet are often neglected and subjected to high demands from activities like running or cycling, practicing this sequence at least once a week helps to rebalance and address this issue.

​

The objectives are to improve mobility in the feet and ankles, stretch the calves and hamstrings, and open up the hips.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Easy Seat
- Box Breathing
- Foot Massage
- Downward Dog
- Screaming Toe
- Yoga Squat
- Ankle Stretch
- Ankle Mobilisations
- Windscreen Wipers

prospects.name: Post-Workout Cool-Down
prospects.description: This gentle cool-down is designed to completely unwind you after your ride…and potentially send you to sleep. We move systematically through the body, loosening up and stretching out tight muscles. Try to stay relaxed throughout while breathing in and out through your nose.

prospects.name: Morning Yoga Routine
prospects.description: In this sequence, we start with a short breathing exercise to relax the body and calm the mind, then mobilize joints throughout the body. From there we move into deeper stretches for the hips and hamstrings and finish with a short meditation.

prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence enhances mobility in the spine and hips while stretching the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, and lower back. As you become familiar with the routine, you can begin to focus on synchronizing your breath with your movements, aiming to use nasal breathing as much as possible. It is an excellent practice for the morning to warm up and improve focus, or it can be done directly after a workout to help prevent extreme muscle stiffness.

​

The objectives are to improve mobility in the spine and hips, stretch the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, and lower back, practice synchronizing breath and movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Half Sun Salutations

- Reclining Spinal Twist
